title: Hokkiens hustle to celebrate Jade Emperor’s birthday
text:
GEORGE TOWN: The Hokkien community is making a beeline for stalls selling food offerings and prayer paraphernalia as it prepares to celebrate the birthday of the Jade Emperor, or Thnee Kong Seh , on the ninth day of Chinese New Year.
Sugarcane stalks, which are one of the main offerings for the Jade Emperor’s birthday celebration that begins tonight, are among the items that have been snapped up.
Sugarcane seller Ch’ng Chai Seah said he prepared about 3,000 sugarcane stalks to sell at his stall in Perak Road, compared to 5,000 last year.
“The supply this year is not as much because of the unpredictable weather.
“But I tried to supply as much as I could because it’s an important offering for the Jade Emperor’s birthday,” he said.
Other items, such as thnee kong kim (pineapple-shaped gold item for the God of Heaven), ngor siew th’ng (pink pagoda-shaped candy), thnee kong poh (offerings folded in “gold” paper), bit chien (skewered sweets) and bee koe (sweet glutinous rice), also sold like hot cakes at various markets.
At the Eng Chin Heong prayer paraphernalia shop in Kimberley Street, customers shopped for joss sticks, kim jua (gold paper), and huge incense sticks.
Shopkeeper Ang Siew Siew, 44, said yesterday that among the popular items was a giant pineapple-shaped thnee kong poh .
“There is also the thnee kong poh made to resemble a pagoda ( yuen bao ta ). These were made using folded kim jua (gold paper) and they signify ‘ bu bu gao sheng ’ (steady progress) or prosperity,” she said.
Ang added that her customers started shopping for the items about three days before the celebration.
From dusk today, altars laden with food offerings and flowers, and flanked by sugarcane stalks, will be set up in front of the homes of devotees and they will wait for midnight, to pay homage to the deity.
The birthday of the Jade Emperor is an important date for the community. According to legend, the Hokkiens survived persecution in ancient China by hiding in a sugarcane plantation for nine days during one Chinese New Year period.
On the ninth day, which coincided with the Jade Emperor’s birthday, they emerged to find their enemies had gone. 
They had been saved by the cover of sugarcane stalks.
Ever since then, Hokkiens have regarded this date as symbolic to their survival.
A check by The Star at Chew Jetty in Weld Quay found Chew Jetty Kongsi chairman Chew Choon Seng overseeing the preparation of the ornate wooden structure that will house a statue of the Jade Emperor during the celebration.
